questions.text: The risk of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is increased in all of the following except –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperopia Vitreoretinal traction is responsible for the occurrence of most RRD . As the vitreous becomes more syneretic (liquefied) with age, a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) occurs. Myopia, aphakia or pseudophakia, familial conditions, and inflammation are among the common causes.

Highyeild:

Retinal necrosis with a retinal break formation occurs; fluid from the vitreous cavity can flow through the breaks and detach the retina without overt vitreoretinal traction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . In most eyes, the vitreous gel separates from the retina without any sequelae. However, in certain eyes, strong vitreoretinal adhesions are present, and the occurrence of a PVD can lead to a retinal tear formation ; then, fluid from the liquefied vitreous can seep under the tear, leading to a retinal detachment. Option: C . A number of conditions exist that predispose to a PVD by prematurely accelerating the liquefaction of the vitreous gel. Option: D . This commonly occurs in acute retinal necrosis syndrome and in cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis in AIDS patients .

Extraedge:

A given amount of vitreoretinal traction will cause retinal tears if the retina is thinner, as in lattice degeneration of the retina.

questions.text: The normal structure of the eye is depicted in the image below. Identify the labeled structures and mark the incorrect statement regarding the structure labeled as D.

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most highly-developed tissue of the eye.

options.label: B
options.text: It is thinnest in the peripapillary region

options.label: C
options.text: The so-called equator separates the posterior pole and peripheral part.

options.label: D
options.text: The posterior pole includes two distinct areas: the optic disc and macula lutea

questions.correct_answer: B. It is thinnest in the peripapillary region
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is thinnest in the peripapillary region The retina, the innermost tunic of the eyeball, is labeled as D in the given image. Retina extends from the optic disc to the ora serrata with a surface area of about 266 mm2. The retina is thickest in the peripapillary region (0.56 mm) and thinnest at the ora serrata (0.1 mm).

Highyeild:

The retinal equator is an imaginary line that is considered to lie in line with the exit of the four vena verticose.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The retina, the innermost tunic of the eyeball, is a thin, delicate, and transparent membrane. It is the most highly-developed tissue of the eye. It appears purplish-red due to the visual purple of the rods and underlying vascular choroid. Option: C. Grossly , it can be divided into two distinct regions: the posterior pole and peripheral retina, separated by the so-called retinal equator. Option: D. The posterior pole refers to the area of the retina posterior to the retinal equator. The posterior pole of the retina includes two distinct areas: the optic disc and the macula lutea. The posterior pole of the retina is best examined by slit-lamp indirect biomicroscopy using +78 D and +90 D lenses and by direct ophthalmoscopy.
